title: Fannie Mae Form 1008 / Freddie Mac Form 1077

personal_information.title: Borrower Personal Information
personal_information.description: Personal details of the primary borrower

borrower_name.title: Borrower Name
borrower_name.description: Full name of the primary borrower
borrower_name.definition: The legal full name of the primary borrower applying for the mortgage loan. This includes first name, middle name or initial, and last name as it appears on official identification documents.

evidence.notes: Name must match across all loan documents and identification

borrower_ssn.title: Borrower SSN
borrower_ssn.description: Social Security Number of the borrower
borrower_ssn.definition: The nine-digit Social Security Number assigned to the primary borrower by the Social Security Administration. This unique identifier is used for credit reporting, income verification, and identity verification purposes throughout the mortgage process.

evidence.notes: SSN must be verified against SSA records and match credit report

income_information.title: Borrower Income Information
income_information.description: Income details of the primary borrower

borrower_base_income.title: Borrower Base Income
borrower_base_income.definition: The primary borrower's stable monthly base income from employment, including regular salary or hourly wages. This is the foundation of qualifying income and must be verified as likely to continue.

evidence.notes: Must demonstrate 2-year history and likelihood of continuance

borrower_other_income.title: Borrower Other Income
borrower_other_income.definition: The primary borrower's stable monthly income from sources other than base employment, including overtime, bonus, commission, self-employment, rental income, retirement, disability, and other documented sources.

evidence.notes: Each income type has specific documentation requirements

borrower_positive_cash_flow_subject_prop.title: Borrower Positive Cash Flow
borrower_positive_cash_flow_subject_prop.definition: Net positive rental income from the subject property attributed to the borrower after deducting PITIA (Principal, Interest, Taxes, Insurance, and Association dues) from gross rental income.

evidence.notes: Only positive cash flow can be added to income

borrower_total_income.title: Borrower Total Income
borrower_total_income.definition: The sum of all qualifying monthly income for the primary borrower, including base income, other income, and positive cash flow from the subject property.

evidence.notes: Total of all borrower income sources

assets_information.title: Borrower Assets Information
assets_information.description: Asset details of the primary borrower

borrower_verified_assets.title: Verified Assets
borrower_verified_assets.definition: The total amount of borrower assets that have been verified and documented as available for the transaction, including checking, savings, investments, and gift funds.

evidence.notes: Must verify sufficient assets to close

borrower_source_of_funds.title: Source of Funds
borrower_source_of_funds.definition: Description of where the borrower's funds for closing will come from, such as checking/savings accounts, sale of assets, gift funds, employer assistance, or other acceptable sources.

evidence.notes: All fund sources must be documented and acceptable

borrower_no_of_months_reserves.title: No. of Months Reserves
borrower_no_of_months_reserves.definition: The number of months of mortgage payments (PITIA) that the borrower will have remaining in verified liquid assets after closing. Reserve requirements vary by property type and occupancy.

evidence.notes: Reserves calculated after funds to close

liabilities_information.title: Borrower Liabilities Information
liabilities_information.description: Liability details of the primary borrower

borrower_present_housing_payment.title: Present Housing Payment
borrower_present_housing_payment.definition: The borrower's current monthly housing expense including rent or mortgage payment, property taxes, insurance, HOA fees, and other housing-related costs. Used to assess payment shock.

evidence.notes: Verify current housing payment for payment shock analysis

borrower_all_other_monthly_payments.title: All Other Monthly Payments
borrower_all_other_monthly_payments.definition: The total of all other monthly debt obligations from the credit report and loan application, including auto loans, student loans, credit cards, child support, alimony, and other recurring debts.

evidence.notes: Include all debts with more than 10 months remaining

credit_information.title: Borrower Credit Information
credit_information.description: Credit details of the primary borrower

borrower_representative_credit_indicator.title: Representative Credit/Indicator Score
borrower_representative_credit_indicator.definition: The credit score used for underwriting and pricing decisions, typically the middle score for a single borrower or the lower of the two middle scores for multiple borrowers.

evidence.notes: Representative score per agency guidelines

co_borrower_1_co_borrower_name.title: Co-Borrower Name
co_borrower_1_co_borrower_name.definition: The legal full name of the co-borrower who shares responsibility for the mortgage loan. A co-borrower's income, assets, and credit history are considered in the loan qualification process.

evidence.notes: Required only if there is a co-borrower on the loan

co_borrower_1_co_borrower_ssn.title: Co-Borrower SSN
co_borrower_1_co_borrower_ssn.description: Social Security Number of the co-borrower
co_borrower_1_co_borrower_ssn.definition: The nine-digit Social Security Number assigned to the co-borrower by the Social Security Administration. Used for credit reporting and verification purposes for the co-borrower.

evidence.notes: Required only if there is a co-borrower on the loan

co_borrower_1_base_income.title: Co-Borrower Base Income
co_borrower_1_base_income.definition: The co-borrower's stable monthly base income from employment, including regular salary or hourly wages. Combined with borrower income for qualification purposes.

evidence.notes: Required only if co-borrower income is used for qualification

co_borrower_1_other_income.title: Co-Borrower Other Income
co_borrower_1_other_income.definition: The co-borrower's stable monthly income from sources other than base employment, including overtime, bonus, commission, self-employment, rental income, retirement, disability, and other documented sources.

evidence.notes: Required only if co-borrower other income is used for qualification

co_borrower_1_positive_cash_flow_subject.title: Co-Borrower Positive Cash Flow
co_borrower_1_positive_cash_flow_subject.definition: Net positive rental income from the subject property attributed to the co-borrower after deducting PITIA from gross rental income.

evidence.notes: Allocation between borrowers if applicable

co_borrower_1_total_income.title: Co-Borrower Total Income
co_borrower_1_total_income.definition: The sum of all qualifying monthly income for the co-borrower, including base income, other income, and positive cash flow from the subject property.

evidence.notes: Total of all co-borrower income sources

property_address.title: Property Address
property_address.description: Full address of the subject property
property_address.definition: The complete street address of the property being financed, including street number, street name, unit number (if applicable), city, state, and ZIP code. This is the collateral property securing the mortgage loan.

evidence.notes: Address must be consistent across all documents

property_number_of_units.title: Number of Units
property_number_of_units.definition: The total number of dwelling units contained within the subject property. For single-family homes this is one; for multi-family properties this ranges from two to four units for residential financing eligibility.

evidence.notes: Determines property type classification and applicable guidelines

property_one_unit.title: 1 Unit
property_one_unit.definition: Indicates the subject property is a single-family dwelling designed for occupancy by one household. This is the most common residential property type for conventional mortgage financing.

evidence.notes: Property type determines applicable guidelines and LTV limits

property_two_to_four_units.title: 2-to 4-units
property_two_to_four_units.definition: Indicates the subject property contains two to four separate dwelling units. These properties are still considered residential for mortgage purposes but have different underwriting requirements and LTV limitations.

evidence.notes: Rental income from additional units may be considered for qualification

property_condominium.title: Condominium
property_condominium.definition: Indicates the subject property is a condominium unit where the borrower owns the individual unit and shares ownership of common areas with other unit owners through a homeowners association.

evidence.notes: Project must meet agency warrantability requirements

property_pud.title: PUD
property_pud.definition: Indicates the subject property is located within a Planned Unit Development, which is a residential community with shared common areas and amenities managed by a homeowners association.

evidence.notes: PUD attachment must be completed on appraisal

property_co_op.title: Co-op
property_co_op.definition: Indicates the subject property is a cooperative housing unit where the borrower purchases shares in a corporation that owns the building, granting the right to occupy a specific unit under a proprietary lease.

evidence.notes: Co-op must be approved by the applicable agency

property_manufactured_housing.title: Manufactured Housing
property_manufactured_housing.definition: Indicates the subject property is a manufactured home built to HUD standards after June 15, 1976, and transported to the site. Must be permanently affixed to a foundation and titled as real property.

evidence.notes: Must meet agency manufactured housing requirements

property_single_wide.title: Single Wide
property_single_wide.definition: Indicates the manufactured home consists of a single transportable section, typically 18 feet or less in width. Single-wide units have more restrictive financing options.

evidence.notes: Single-wide eligibility varies by agency and program

property_multiwide.title: Multiwide
property_multiwide.definition: Indicates the manufactured home consists of two or more transportable sections joined together at the site to form a single dwelling unit, commonly referred to as double-wide or triple-wide.

evidence.notes: Multi-section homes generally have broader eligibility

property_primary_residence.title: Primary Residence
property_primary_residence.definition: Indicates the borrower intends to occupy the subject property as their principal dwelling. Primary residence occupancy typically qualifies for the most favorable loan terms and lowest down payment requirements.

evidence.notes: Borrower must certify intent to occupy within 60 days of closing

property_second_home.title: Second Home
property_second_home.definition: Indicates the subject property will be occupied by the borrower for a portion of the year but is not their primary residence. Second homes must be suitable for year-round occupancy and located a reasonable distance from the primary residence.

evidence.notes: Property must meet second home eligibility requirements

property_investment_property.title: Investment Property
property_investment_property.definition: Indicates the subject property will not be occupied by the borrower and is being acquired for rental income or investment purposes. Investment properties have stricter underwriting requirements and higher down payment requirements.

evidence.notes: Investment properties have higher LTV restrictions

property_rights.title: Property Rights
property_rights.description: Fee simple, leasehold, and other property rights

property_fee_simple.title: Fee Simple
property_fee_simple.definition: Indicates the borrower will hold absolute ownership of the property and land with no limitations on transfer or use other than governmental restrictions. This is the most complete form of property ownership.

evidence.notes: Most common ownership type for residential properties

property_leasehold.title: Leasehold
property_leasehold.definition: Indicates the borrower will own the improvements but lease the underlying land from a third party under a ground lease. Leasehold properties have specific eligibility requirements regarding lease terms and provisions.

evidence.notes: Ground lease must meet agency requirements for term and provisions

property_valuation.title: Property Valuation
property_valuation.description: Appraised value and sale price information

property_sales_price.title: Sales Price
property_sales_price.definition: The agreed-upon purchase price for the subject property as stated in the executed purchase agreement between the buyer and seller. This amount is used in calculating LTV ratios for purchase transactions.

evidence.notes: Must match the contract sales price; adjustments for seller concessions may apply

property_appraised_value.title: Appraised Value
property_appraised_value.definition: The market value of the subject property as determined by a licensed appraiser in the appraisal report. This value represents the appraiser's opinion of the property's worth based on comparable sales and market analysis.

evidence.notes: LTV calculations use the lesser of appraised value or sales price for purchases

project_information.title: Project Information
project_information.description: Project classification and details for condos, PUDs, and co-ops

property_project_name.title: Project Name
property_project_name.definition: The official name of the condominium, PUD, or cooperative project as registered with the applicable homeowners association or cooperative corporation. Used for project identification and eligibility verification.

evidence.notes: Must match project name in agency databases

property_cpm_project_id.title: CPM Project ID# (if any)
property_cpm_project_id.definition: The Condo Project Manager (CPM) identification number assigned by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac to approved condominium projects. This unique identifier is used to track project eligibility status.

evidence.notes: Only applicable for projects with agency approval

property_streamlined_review.title: Streamlined Review
property_streamlined_review.definition: A Freddie Mac project review type for established condominium projects that meet specific eligibility criteria, allowing for a simplified review process with reduced documentation requirements.

evidence.notes: Project must meet Freddie Mac streamlined review eligibility

property_established_project.title: Established Project
property_established_project.definition: A Freddie Mac classification for condominium or PUD projects that have been completed, are no longer under developer control, and have an established track record of owner occupancy and financial stability.

evidence.notes: Project must demonstrate established status criteria

property_new_project.title: New Project
property_new_project.definition: A Freddie Mac classification for newly constructed or converted condominium projects that may still be under developer control or have not yet established a sufficient operating history.

evidence.notes: New projects require additional review and documentation

property_detached_project.title: Detached Project
property_detached_project.definition: A Freddie Mac classification for condominium or PUD projects consisting entirely of detached single-family dwellings, which typically have simplified review requirements.

evidence.notes: Detached projects may qualify for limited review

property_two_to_four_unit_project.title: 2- to 4-unit Project
property_two_to_four_unit_project.definition: A Freddie Mac classification for condominium projects where individual units contain two to four dwelling units, subject to specific eligibility and review requirements.

evidence.notes: Multi-unit condos have specific eligibility criteria

property_reciprocal_review.title: Reciprocal Review
property_reciprocal_review.definition: A Freddie Mac project review type that accepts project approvals previously completed by Fannie Mae under their PERS (Project Eligibility Review Service) process.

evidence.notes: Requires valid Fannie Mae project approval

property_p_limited_review_new_detached.title: P Limited Review New Detached
property_p_limited_review_new_detached.definition: Fannie Mae project classification P for new detached condominium units that qualify for limited project review due to the detached nature of the units and reduced project risk.

evidence.notes: Applicable to detached condo units in new projects

property_q_limited_review_established.title: Q Limited Review Established
property_q_limited_review_established.definition: Fannie Mae project classification Q for established condominium projects that qualify for limited project review based on meeting specific eligibility criteria including owner occupancy and financial stability.

evidence.notes: Project must meet established project criteria

property_r_expedited_review_new.title: R Expedited Review New
property_r_expedited_review_new.definition: Fannie Mae project classification R for new condominium projects requiring expedited review, which involves a more thorough analysis than limited review but less than full review.

evidence.notes: New projects not qualifying for limited review

property_s_expedited_review_established.title: S Expedited Review Established
property_s_expedited_review_established.definition: Fannie Mae project classification S for established condominium projects requiring expedited review due to not meeting all limited review criteria but not requiring full review.

evidence.notes: Established projects not qualifying for limited review

property_t_fannie_mae_review.title: T Fannie Mae Review
property_t_fannie_mae_review.definition: Fannie Mae project classification T indicating the project requires full review by Fannie Mae through their Project Eligibility Review Service (PERS) due to complexity or risk factors.

evidence.notes: Full PERS review required for project approval

property_u_fha_approved.title: U FHA-approved
property_u_fha_approved.definition: Fannie Mae project classification U for condominium projects that have received FHA approval, which may be accepted by Fannie Mae under certain circumstances.

evidence.notes: FHA approval must be current and valid

property_v_refi_plus.title: V Refi Plus™
property_v_refi_plus.definition: Fannie Mae project classification V for condominium units being refinanced under the Refi Plus program, which has specific project review requirements for refinance transactions.

evidence.notes: Applicable to Refi Plus refinance transactions only

property_e_pud.title: E PUD
property_e_pud.definition: Fannie Mae project classification E for Planned Unit Development projects that meet established project criteria and qualify for standard PUD review.

evidence.notes: Standard PUD classification

property_f_pud.title: F PUD
property_f_pud.definition: Fannie Mae project classification F for Planned Unit Development projects requiring additional review due to specific project characteristics or risk factors.

evidence.notes: PUD requiring enhanced review

property_t_pud.title: T PUD
property_t_pud.definition: Fannie Mae project classification T for Planned Unit Development projects requiring full Fannie Mae review through PERS due to complexity or risk factors.

evidence.notes: Full PERS review required for PUD

property_one_co_op.title: 1 Co-op
property_one_co_op.definition: Fannie Mae project classification 1 for cooperative housing projects that meet standard eligibility requirements and have been approved for Fannie Mae financing.

evidence.notes: Standard co-op project classification

property_two_co_op.title: 2 Co-op
property_two_co_op.definition: Fannie Mae project classification 2 for cooperative housing projects requiring additional review or having specific characteristics that differentiate them from standard co-op projects.

evidence.notes: Co-op requiring enhanced review

property_t_co_op.title: T Co-op
property_t_co_op.definition: Fannie Mae project classification T for cooperative housing projects requiring full Fannie Mae review due to complexity, risk factors, or not meeting standard approval criteria.

evidence.notes: Full PERS review required for co-op

loan_terms.title: Loan Terms
loan_terms.description: Amount, rate, term, and type information

loan_original_loan_amount.title: Original Loan Amount
loan_original_loan_amount.definition: The principal amount of the mortgage loan as stated on the promissory note. This is the total amount borrowed before any payments are made and is used to calculate LTV ratios.

evidence.notes: Must match the note amount exactly

loan_initial_note_rate.title: Initial Note Rate
loan_initial_note_rate.definition: The initial interest rate stated on the promissory note, expressed as an annual percentage. For fixed-rate loans this rate applies for the entire term; for ARMs this is the rate during the initial fixed period.

evidence.notes: Rate must match the promissory note

loan_initial_p_and_i_payment.title: Initial P&I Payment
loan_initial_p_and_i_payment.definition: The initial monthly principal and interest payment amount due on the mortgage loan. For fixed-rate loans this remains constant; for ARMs this is the payment during the initial fixed period.

evidence.notes: Does not include taxes, insurance, or other escrows

loan_term_in_months.title: Loan Term (in months)
loan_term_in_months.definition: The total duration of the mortgage loan expressed in months, representing the time period over which the loan will be fully amortized. Common terms are 360 months (30 years) and 180 months (15 years).

evidence.notes: Term affects payment amount and total interest paid

loan_conventional.title: Conventional
loan_conventional.definition: Indicates the mortgage loan is not insured or guaranteed by a government agency. Conventional loans are originated and funded by private lenders and may be sold to Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac.

evidence.notes: Conventional loans follow agency guidelines

loan_fha.title: FHA
loan_fha.definition: Indicates the mortgage loan is insured by the Federal Housing Administration, a government agency within HUD. FHA loans have specific requirements and mortgage insurance premiums.

evidence.notes: FHA loans require upfront and annual MIP

loan_va.title: VA
loan_va.definition: Indicates the mortgage loan is guaranteed by the Department of Veterans Affairs for eligible veterans, active-duty service members, and surviving spouses. VA loans offer favorable terms including no down payment.

evidence.notes: Borrower must have valid VA entitlement

loan_usda_rhs.title: USDA/RHS
loan_usda_rhs.definition: Indicates the mortgage loan is guaranteed by the United States Department of Agriculture Rural Housing Service for properties in eligible rural areas. USDA loans offer 100% financing for qualified borrowers.

evidence.notes: Property must be in USDA-eligible rural area

loan_fixed_rate_monthly_payments.title: Fixed-Rate—Monthly Payments
loan_fixed_rate_monthly_payments.definition: Indicates the mortgage has a fixed interest rate that remains constant throughout the loan term with equal monthly principal and interest payments. This is the most common amortization type.

evidence.notes: Rate and payment remain constant for loan term

loan_fixed_rate_biweekly_payments.title: Fixed-Rate—Biweekly Payments
loan_fixed_rate_biweekly_payments.definition: Indicates the mortgage has a fixed interest rate with payments made every two weeks instead of monthly, resulting in 26 half-payments per year and accelerated principal paydown.

evidence.notes: Results in equivalent of 13 monthly payments per year

loan_balloon.title: Balloon
loan_balloon.definition: Indicates the mortgage has a large lump-sum payment due at the end of the loan term, with regular payments during the term that do not fully amortize the loan balance.

evidence.notes: Balloon mortgages have limited eligibility

loan_arm.title: ARM (type)
loan_arm.definition: Indicates the mortgage is an Adjustable-Rate Mortgage where the interest rate may change periodically based on a specified index plus margin, subject to rate caps and adjustment periods.

evidence.notes: ARM terms must be clearly disclosed

loan_arm_type.title: ARM Type Description
loan_arm_type.definition: Specifies the particular ARM product structure including the initial fixed-rate period and subsequent adjustment frequency, such as 5/1 ARM (fixed for 5 years, adjusts annually thereafter).

evidence.notes: Common types include 3/1, 5/1, 7/1, and 10/1 ARMs

loan_other.title: Other (specify)
loan_other.definition: Indicates the mortgage has an amortization type other than the standard options listed, requiring specification of the unique payment or amortization structure.

evidence.notes: Must specify the amortization type

loan_other_specify.title: Other Amortization Type Specification
loan_other_specify.definition: Description of the non-standard amortization type when 'Other' is selected, providing details on the specific payment structure or amortization method.

evidence.notes: Required when Other amortization is selected

loan_purchase.title: Purchase
loan_purchase.definition: Indicates the loan proceeds will be used to acquire the subject property. Purchase transactions require a sales contract and use the lesser of sales price or appraised value for LTV calculations.

evidence.notes: Requires executed purchase contract

loan_cash_out_refinance.title: Cash-Out Refinance
loan_cash_out_refinance.definition: Indicates the loan is a refinance transaction where the borrower receives cash proceeds exceeding the payoff of existing liens, closing costs, and prepaids. Cash-out refinances have stricter LTV limits.

evidence.notes: Cash-out amount subject to agency limits

loan_limited_cash_out_refinance_fannie.title: Limited Cash-Out Refinance (Fannie)
loan_limited_cash_out_refinance_fannie.definition: A Fannie Mae refinance transaction where cash back to the borrower is limited to the lesser of 2% of the new loan amount or $2,000. Used to refinance existing debt without significant cash extraction.

evidence.notes: Fannie Mae specific refinance type

loan_no_cash_out_refinance_freddie.title: No Cash-Out Refinance (Freddie)
loan_no_cash_out_refinance_freddie.definition: A Freddie Mac refinance transaction where the borrower does not receive cash proceeds beyond a minimal amount for incidental costs. Similar to Fannie Mae's limited cash-out refinance.

evidence.notes: Freddie Mac specific refinance type

loan_home_improvement.title: Home Improvement
loan_home_improvement.definition: Indicates loan proceeds will be used for renovations, repairs, or improvements to the subject property. May be combined with purchase or refinance transactions.

evidence.notes: May require renovation loan program

loan_construction_to_permanent.title: Construction to Permanent
loan_construction_to_permanent.definition: Indicates a loan that converts from a construction loan to permanent mortgage financing upon completion of construction. Combines construction and permanent financing into a single transaction.

evidence.notes: Requires construction loan documentation

loan_ltv.title: LTV
loan_ltv.definition: The Loan-to-Value ratio calculated by dividing the first mortgage loan amount by the lesser of the appraised value or sales price (for purchases), expressed as a percentage.

evidence.notes: Primary LTV ratio for first mortgage

loan_cltv_tltv.title: CLTV/TLTV
loan_cltv_tltv.definition: The Combined Loan-to-Value ratio calculated by dividing the total of all mortgage liens (first mortgage plus subordinate financing balances) by the property value, expressed as a percentage.

evidence.notes: Includes all mortgage liens on property

loan_hcltv_htltv.title: HCLTV/HTLTV
loan_hcltv_htltv.definition: The HELOC Combined Loan-to-Value ratio calculated using the full credit limit of any HELOC (not just the balance) plus all other mortgage liens, divided by property value.

evidence.notes: Uses full HELOC credit limit, not balance

loan_primary_housing_expense_income.title: Primary Housing Expense/Income
loan_primary_housing_expense_income.definition: The front-end debt-to-income ratio calculated by dividing the total primary housing expense by the total qualifying monthly income, expressed as a percentage. Also known as the housing ratio.

evidence.notes: Front-end DTI ratio

loan_total_obligations_income.title: Total Obligations/Income
loan_total_obligations_income.definition: The back-end debt-to-income ratio calculated by dividing total monthly obligations (housing plus all other debts) by total qualifying monthly income, expressed as a percentage.

evidence.notes: Back-end DTI ratio - primary qualifying ratio

loan_debt_to_housing_gap_ratio_freddie.title: Debt-to-Housing Gap Ratio (Freddie)
loan_debt_to_housing_gap_ratio_freddie.definition: A Freddie Mac-specific ratio that measures the difference between the total DTI and housing DTI, indicating the proportion of non-housing debt relative to income.

evidence.notes: Freddie Mac specific calculation

loan_first_mortgage.title: First Mortgage
loan_first_mortgage.definition: Indicates the mortgage being originated will hold first lien position on the subject property, having priority over all other liens except property taxes and special assessments.

evidence.notes: First lien position must be confirmed by title

loan_second_mortgage.title: Second Mortgage
loan_second_mortgage.definition: Indicates the mortgage being originated will hold second lien position on the subject property, subordinate to an existing first mortgage that will remain in place.

evidence.notes: Second mortgages have specific eligibility requirements

loan_amount_of_subordinate_financing.title: Amount of Subordinate Financing
loan_amount_of_subordinate_financing.definition: The total outstanding balance of all subordinate liens (second mortgages, HELOCs, etc.) that will remain on the property after closing. Used in calculating CLTV ratios.

evidence.notes: All subordinate liens must be disclosed

loan_heloc_include_balance_and_credit_li.title: If HELOC, include balance and credit limit
loan_heloc_include_balance_and_credit_li.definition: For Home Equity Lines of Credit, both the current outstanding balance and the total credit limit must be disclosed as the full credit limit is used in HCLTV calculations.

evidence.notes: HCLTV uses full credit limit, not just balance

loan_seller.title: Seller
loan_seller.definition: Indicates the loan was originated directly by the seller/servicer who will be delivering the loan to Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac, without involvement of a third-party broker or correspondent.

evidence.notes: Direct lending channel

loan_broker.title: Broker
loan_broker.definition: Indicates the loan was originated through a mortgage broker who facilitated the transaction but did not fund the loan. The broker acts as an intermediary between the borrower and the funding lender.

evidence.notes: Broker compensation must be disclosed

loan_correspondent.title: Correspondent
loan_correspondent.definition: Indicates the loan was originated by a correspondent lender who funded the loan in their own name and subsequently sells it to a larger lender or aggregator for delivery to the agencies.

evidence.notes: Correspondent funded the loan initially

loan_broker_correspondent_name_and_compa.title: Broker/Correspondent Name and Company Name
loan_broker_correspondent_name_and_compa.definition: The name of the individual loan originator and their company when the loan was originated through a broker or correspondent channel. Required for tracking and compliance purposes.

evidence.notes: Must include NMLS ID numbers

loan_yes.title: Yes
loan_yes.definition: Indicates the loan includes a temporary or permanent buydown where discount points or funds are used to reduce the interest rate below the standard market rate.

evidence.notes: Buydown terms must be documented

loan_no.title: No
loan_no.definition: Indicates the loan does not include any buydown arrangement and the borrower is paying the standard note rate without any rate reduction from discount points or buydown funds.

evidence.notes: Standard rate without buydown

loan_terms.title: Terms
loan_terms.definition: Description of the buydown structure including the initial reduced rate, the duration of the buydown period, and the rate adjustment schedule (e.g., 2-1 buydown, 3-2-1 buydown).

evidence.notes: Required when buydown is selected

if_second_mortgage.title: If Second Mortgage
if_second_mortgage.description: Information when loan is a second mortgage

loan_fannie_mae.title: Fannie Mae
loan_fannie_mae.definition: Indicates the first mortgage on the subject property is owned or securitized by Fannie Mae. This information is relevant for subordinate financing eligibility and CLTV calculations.

evidence.notes: Can be verified through Fannie Mae loan lookup

loan_freddie_mac.title: Freddie Mac
loan_freddie_mac.definition: Indicates the first mortgage on the subject property is owned or securitized by Freddie Mac. This information is relevant for subordinate financing eligibility and CLTV calculations.

evidence.notes: Can be verified through Freddie Mac loan lookup

loan_seller_other.title: Seller/Other
loan_seller_other.definition: Indicates the first mortgage on the subject property is owned by the seller, a portfolio lender, or another entity other than Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac.

evidence.notes: Identify the specific owner/servicer

loan_original_loan_amount_of_first_mortg.title: Original Loan Amount of First Mortgage
loan_original_loan_amount_of_first_mortg.definition: The original principal balance of the first mortgage at origination. Used in conjunction with current balance to understand the equity position and calculate combined loan-to-value ratios.

evidence.notes: Original amount, not current balance

underwriting_information.title: Underwriting Information
underwriting_information.description: Underwriting findings, risk assessment, and conditions

underwriters_name.title: Underwriter's Name
underwriters_name.definition: The name of the mortgage underwriter who reviewed and approved the loan file. The underwriter is responsible for verifying that the loan meets all applicable guidelines and represents an acceptable credit risk.

evidence.notes: Underwriter must be authorized to approve loans

base_income_total.title: Total Base Income
base_income_total.definition: The combined total monthly base income from both borrower and co-borrower. This sum represents the primary qualifying income before adding other income sources.

evidence.notes: Calculated field - sum of borrower and co-borrower base income

other_income_total.title: Total Other Income
other_income_total.definition: The combined total monthly other income from both borrower and co-borrower from all non-base income sources used for qualification.

evidence.notes: Calculated field - sum of borrower and co-borrower other income

positive_cash_flow_total.title: Total Positive Cash Flow
positive_cash_flow_total.definition: The combined total positive cash flow from the subject property that can be added to qualifying income for both borrower and co-borrower.

evidence.notes: Calculated field - only positive amounts included

total_income.title: Total Income
total_income.definition: The combined total qualifying monthly income from all borrowers used for debt-to-income ratio calculations and loan qualification.

evidence.notes: Primary income figure for DTI calculations

first_mortgage_p_and_i.title: First Mortgage P&I
first_mortgage_p_and_i.definition: The proposed monthly principal and interest payment on the first mortgage for the subject property. This is the base housing payment before adding taxes, insurance, and other costs.

evidence.notes: Must match note P&I payment

second_mortgage_p_and_i.title: Second Mortgage P&I
second_mortgage_p_and_i.definition: The monthly principal and interest payment on any second mortgage or subordinate financing on the subject property that will exist after closing.

evidence.notes: Include if subordinate financing exists

hazard_insurance.title: Hazard Insurance
hazard_insurance.definition: The monthly amount for property hazard insurance (homeowners insurance) that protects against fire, wind, and other covered perils. Required for all mortgage loans.

evidence.notes: Must meet agency minimum coverage requirements

taxes.title: Taxes
taxes.definition: The monthly amount for real estate property taxes on the subject property, calculated by dividing the annual tax amount by twelve months.

evidence.notes: Use current or estimated annual taxes divided by 12

mortgage_insurance.title: Mortgage Insurance
mortgage_insurance.definition: The monthly mortgage insurance premium required when the LTV exceeds 80% for conventional loans, or the monthly portion of FHA MIP or VA funding fee if applicable.

evidence.notes: Required when LTV exceeds 80% for conventional

hoa_fees.title: HOA Fees
hoa_fees.definition: The monthly homeowners association fees or condominium association dues required for properties in planned communities, condominiums, or cooperatives.

evidence.notes: Include all mandatory HOA/condo fees

lease_ground_rent.title: Lease/Ground Rent
lease_ground_rent.definition: The monthly ground rent payment for leasehold properties where the borrower owns the improvements but leases the underlying land from a third party.

evidence.notes: Only applicable for leasehold properties

other.title: Other
other.definition: Any other monthly housing expenses not captured in the standard categories, such as special assessments, flood insurance, or other property-related charges.

evidence.notes: Specify the nature of other expenses

total_primary_housing_expense.title: Total Primary Housing Expense
total_primary_housing_expense.definition: The sum of all proposed monthly housing expenses (PITIA) for the subject property, used as the numerator in the front-end debt-to-income ratio calculation.

evidence.notes: Sum of all housing expense components

negative_cash_flow_subject_property.title: Negative Cash Flow (subject property)
negative_cash_flow_subject_property.definition: Net negative rental income from the subject property when the PITIA expenses exceed the gross rental income. This amount is added to monthly obligations for DTI calculations.

evidence.notes: Negative cash flow increases total obligations

all_other_monthly_payments.title: All Other Monthly Payments
all_other_monthly_payments.definition: The total of all other monthly debt obligations from the credit report and loan application, including auto loans, student loans, credit cards, child support, alimony, and other recurring debts.

evidence.notes: Include all debts with more than 10 months remaining

total_all_monthly_payments.title: Total All Monthly Payments
total_all_monthly_payments.definition: The sum of total primary housing expense, negative cash flow, and all other monthly payments. This is the total monthly debt obligation used in the back-end DTI ratio calculation.

evidence.notes: Total obligations for DTI calculation

required.title: Required
required.definition: The total amount of funds the borrower must bring to closing, including down payment, closing costs, prepaids, and reserves minus any credits or seller contributions.

evidence.notes: Net funds required from borrower

verified_assets.title: Verified Assets
verified_assets.definition: The total amount of borrower assets that have been verified and documented as available for the transaction, including checking, savings, investments, and gift funds.

evidence.notes: Must verify sufficient assets to close

interested_party_contributions.title: Interested Party Contributions
interested_party_contributions.definition: The total amount of closing costs, prepaids, and other fees paid by interested parties (seller, real estate agent, builder, etc.) expressed as a percentage of the sales price or appraised value.

evidence.notes: IPC limits vary by LTV and occupancy

manual_underwriting.title: Manual Underwriting
manual_underwriting.definition: Indicates the loan was underwritten manually by a human underwriter without reliance on an automated underwriting system recommendation, typically due to AUS referral or ineligibility.

evidence.notes: Manual UW has specific documentation requirements

aus.title: AUS
aus.definition: Indicates the loan was submitted to an Automated Underwriting System for risk assessment and received a recommendation that was used in the underwriting decision.

evidence.notes: AUS findings must be in file

du.title: DU
du.definition: Indicates the loan was submitted to Fannie Mae's Desktop Underwriter (DU) automated underwriting system for risk assessment and eligibility determination.

evidence.notes: Fannie Mae's automated underwriting system

lp.title: LP
lp.definition: Indicates the loan was submitted to Freddie Mac's Loan Product Advisor (LP) automated underwriting system for risk assessment and eligibility determination.

evidence.notes: Freddie Mac's automated underwriting system

other.title: Other
other.definition: Indicates the loan was submitted to an automated underwriting system other than DU or LP, such as a proprietary system or government AUS.

evidence.notes: Specify the AUS system used

other_specify.title: Other AUS Specification
other_specify.definition: The name of the automated underwriting system used when 'Other' is selected, such as FHA TOTAL Scorecard, VA LAPP, or a proprietary system.

evidence.notes: Required when Other AUS is selected

aus_recommendation.title: AUS Recommendation
aus_recommendation.definition: The risk assessment recommendation returned by the automated underwriting system, such as Approve/Eligible, Accept, Refer, or Caution. This recommendation guides underwriting decisions.

evidence.notes: Must document the AUS recommendation

du_case_id_lp_aus_key.title: DU Case ID/LP AUS Key#
du_case_id_lp_aus_key.definition: The unique identifier assigned by the automated underwriting system to the loan submission, used to retrieve findings and track the loan through the system.

evidence.notes: Required for AUS-underwritten loans

lp_doc_class_freddie.title: LP Doc Class (Freddie)
lp_doc_class_freddie.definition: The documentation classification assigned by Freddie Mac's Loan Product Advisor indicating the level of income and asset documentation required, such as Standard or Streamlined.

evidence.notes: Freddie Mac specific documentation classification

note_rate.title: Note Rate
note_rate.definition: Indicates the borrower is being qualified at the actual note rate stated on the promissory note, typically used for fixed-rate mortgages.

evidence.notes: Standard qualification for fixed-rate loans

note_rate_value.title: Note Rate Value
note_rate_value.definition: The actual interest rate from the promissory note used for qualifying the borrower when qualifying at the note rate.

evidence.notes: Must match the promissory note rate

percent_above_note_rate.title: % Above Note Rate
percent_above_note_rate.definition: The percentage added to the note rate for qualification purposes, typically used for ARM loans where borrowers must qualify at a rate higher than the initial rate.

evidence.notes: ARM qualification may require qualifying at higher rate

percent_below_note_rate.title: % Below Note Rate
percent_below_note_rate.definition: The percentage subtracted from the note rate for qualification purposes, which may apply in certain buydown scenarios or special programs.

evidence.notes: Rare - typically for buydown qualification

bought_down_rate.title: Bought-Down Rate
bought_down_rate.definition: Indicates the borrower is being qualified at a temporarily reduced interest rate due to a buydown arrangement where funds are deposited to subsidize payments.

evidence.notes: Buydown qualification requirements vary by program

bought_down_rate_value.title: Bought-Down Rate Value
bought_down_rate_value.definition: The reduced interest rate used for qualification when a buydown is in effect, representing the initial subsidized rate during the buydown period.

evidence.notes: Initial rate during buydown period

other.title: Other
other.definition: Indicates the borrower is being qualified at a rate other than the standard note rate or bought-down rate, requiring specification of the qualifying rate used.

evidence.notes: Must specify the qualifying rate methodology

other_value.title: Other Rate Value
other_value.definition: The specific interest rate used for qualification when 'Other' qualifying rate is selected, with documentation of the basis for using this rate.

evidence.notes: Required when Other qualifying rate is selected

yes.title: Yes
yes.definition: Indicates the loan will include an escrow account for the collection and payment of property taxes and hazard insurance, with monthly escrow deposits included in the mortgage payment.

evidence.notes: Escrow may be required based on LTV or state law

no.title: No
no.definition: Indicates the loan will not include an escrow account, and the borrower will be responsible for paying property taxes and insurance directly. Escrow waivers have specific eligibility requirements.

evidence.notes: Escrow waiver eligibility varies by LTV and state

yes.title: Yes
yes.definition: Indicates the loan is being originated under a community lending or affordable housing program designed to expand homeownership opportunities for low-to-moderate income borrowers or underserved communities.

evidence.notes: Must meet program eligibility requirements

no.title: No
no.definition: Indicates the loan is not being originated under any community lending or affordable housing initiative and follows standard underwriting guidelines.

evidence.notes: Standard loan not under special program

home_buyers_homeownership_education_cert.title: Home Buyers/Homeownership Education Certificate in file

yes.title: Yes
yes.definition: Indicates the borrower has completed a homebuyer education or homeownership counseling course and a certificate of completion is included in the loan file.

evidence.notes: May be required for certain programs or first-time buyers

no.title: No
no.definition: Indicates no homebuyer education certificate is in the loan file, either because it was not required or the borrower did not complete a course.

evidence.notes: Document if education was required but waived

underwriter_comments.title: Underwriter Comments
underwriter_comments.definition: Free-form text field for the underwriter to document any additional information, explanations, compensating factors, or conditions related to the loan approval decision.

evidence.notes: Used to document compensating factors and special circumstances

appraisers_name_license_number.title: Appraiser's Name/License #
appraisers_name_license_number.definition: The name and state license number of the appraiser who completed the property appraisal. Appraisers must be state-licensed or certified and meet agency appraiser independence requirements.

evidence.notes: License must be verified as active and in good standing

appraisal_company_name.title: Appraisal Company Name
appraisal_company_name.definition: The name of the appraisal management company or appraisal firm that assigned or employed the appraiser. Required for tracking appraiser independence and compliance with USPAP standards.

evidence.notes: AMC must be properly registered if applicable

appraisal_data.title: Appraisal Data
appraisal_data.description: Level of property review and appraisal form information

exterior_interior.title: Exterior/Interior
exterior_interior.definition: Indicates a full appraisal was completed with both exterior and interior inspection of the subject property, providing the most comprehensive property valuation.

evidence.notes: Standard full appraisal with interior inspection

exterior_only.title: Exterior Only
exterior_only.definition: Indicates an appraisal was completed with only an exterior inspection of the subject property, without interior access. Used for certain refinance transactions or when interior access is not required.

evidence.notes: Drive-by or exterior-only appraisal

no_appraisal.title: No Appraisal
no_appraisal.definition: Indicates no traditional appraisal was required for the transaction, typically due to an appraisal waiver from the automated underwriting system based on data confidence.

evidence.notes: PIW or appraisal waiver from AUS

form_number.title: Form Number
form_number.definition: The specific appraisal form number used for the property valuation, such as Form 1004 (URAR), Form 1073 (Condo), Form 1025 (Small Income), or Form 2055 (Exterior-Only).

evidence.notes: Form type must be appropriate for property type

transaction_seller_name.title: Seller Name
transaction_seller_name.definition: The name of the mortgage seller/servicer or correspondent lender delivering the loan to Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac for purchase or securitization.

evidence.notes: Must be an approved seller/servicer

transaction_seller_address.title: Seller Address
transaction_seller_address.definition: The business address of the mortgage seller/servicer delivering the loan, used for correspondence and contract purposes.

evidence.notes: Corporate address of seller/servicer

transaction_seller_no.title: Seller No.
transaction_seller_no.definition: The unique identification number assigned to the seller/servicer by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac for tracking and contract purposes.

evidence.notes: Agency-assigned seller number

transaction_investor_loan_no.title: Investor Loan No.
transaction_investor_loan_no.definition: The loan identification number assigned by the investor or agency purchasing the loan, used for tracking after delivery.

evidence.notes: Assigned upon loan delivery

transaction_seller_loan_no.title: Seller Loan No.
transaction_seller_loan_no.definition: The internal loan identification number assigned by the seller/servicer's loan origination system for tracking throughout the origination and delivery process.

evidence.notes: Internal tracking number

transaction_contact_name.title: Contact Name
transaction_contact_name.definition: The name of the individual at the seller/servicer organization who can be contacted regarding questions about the loan file or delivery.

evidence.notes: Primary contact for loan inquiries

transaction_contact_title.title: Contact Title
transaction_contact_title.definition: The job title or position of the contact person at the seller/servicer organization.

evidence.notes: Title of primary contact

transaction_contact_phone_number.title: Contact Phone Number
transaction_contact_phone_number.definition: The telephone number for the contact person at the seller/servicer organization for loan-related inquiries.

evidence.notes: Direct phone number for contact

transaction_contact_phone_ext.title: Contact Phone Extension
transaction_contact_phone_ext.definition: The telephone extension number for the contact person, if applicable.

evidence.notes: Extension if applicable

transaction_contact_signature.title: Contact Signature
transaction_contact_signature.definition: The signature of the authorized representative of the seller/servicer certifying the accuracy of the information on the transmittal summary and compliance with applicable guidelines.

evidence.notes: Authorized signature required for delivery

freddie_mac_form_number.title: Freddie Mac Form Number
freddie_mac_form_number.definition: The official Freddie Mac form number for the Uniform Underwriting and Transmittal Summary, which is Form 1077.

evidence.notes: Standard form number

fannie_mae_form_number.title: Fannie Mae Form Number
fannie_mae_form_number.definition: The official Fannie Mae form number for the Uniform Underwriting and Transmittal Summary, which is Form 1008.

evidence.notes: Standard form number

form_revision_date.title: Form Revision Date
form_revision_date.definition: The date of the most recent revision to the form, indicating which version of the form is being used for the loan file.

evidence.notes: Form version tracking

page_number.title: Page Number
page_number.definition: The page number within the form document, used for multi-page forms to ensure completeness.

evidence.notes: Page tracking for form completeness
